inlineContent.text: Use a pooling layer to downsample an input, selecting, for example, the average or the maximum value in a specified kernel size. The following figure illustrates how a 2 x 2 maximum pooling kernel samples each 2 x 2 block of values of 4 x 4 source. The highlighted block contains the values

abstract.text: Make large-scale mathematical computations and image calculations, optimized for high performance and low energy consumption.
A layer object that wraps a pooling filter and manages its deinitialization.
A constant that represents a 3D image stack.
An opaque type that represents a filter.
Returns a pooling  filter, initialized with input, output, layer, and filter parameters.
A structure that contains common filter parameters.
A structure that contains the parameters of a pooling layer.
The width padding, which is the number of virtual zeros added to the left and right of each channel.
The height padding, which is the number of virtual zeros added to the top and bottom of each channel.
Applies a pooling filter backward to generate gradients.
Applies a pooling filter backward to generate gradients with support for multiple data types for indices.
Applies a pooling filter to a set of input objects, writing the result to a set of output objects.
Applies a pooling filter to a set of input objects with support for multiple data types for indices.
A function for pooling that’s the partial inverse of max pooling and sets all nonmaximal values to zero.
A structure containing pooling layer parameters.
A pointer for accessing data of a specific type.

media-3633103.alt: Figure that shows a two dimensional four times four source matrix downsampled using a two times two pooling kernel that returns a three times three result. The operation writes the maximum value of each two times two block from the source matrix to the result.
